			</script><meta content="Receptor for glucocorticoids (GC) (PubMed:27120390). Has a dual mode of action: as a transcription factor that binds to glucocorticoid response elements (GRE), both for nuclear and mitochondrial DNA, and as a modulator of other transcription factors. Affects inflammatory responses, cellular proliferation and differentiation in target tissues. Involved in chromatin remodeling (PubMed:9590696). Plays a role in rapid mRNA degradation by binding to the 5' UTR of target mRNAs and interacting with PNRC2 in a ligand-dependent manner which recruits the RNA helicase UPF1 and the mRNA-decapping enzyme DCP1A, leading to RNA decay (PubMed:25775514). Could act as a coactivator for STAT5-dependent transcription upon growth hormone (GH) stimulation and could reveal an essential role of hepatic GR in the control of body growth (By similarity)." name="description"/><meta content="nositelinkssearchbox" name="google"/></head><body class="namespace-uniprot" typeof="WebPage" prefix="up: http://purl.uniprot.org/core/" vocab="http://schema.org/"><span id="evidenceToolTip" style="display:none">&#xd;
                                    &lt;p>An evidence describes the source of an annotation, e.g. an experiment that has been published in the scientific literature, an orthologous protein, a record from another database, etc.&lt;/p>&#xd;
&#xd;
&lt;p>&lt;a href="/manual/evidences">More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p>&#xd;

property="name">Glucocorticoid receptor</h1></div><div class="entry-overview-header">Gene</div><div id="content-gene" class="entry-overview-content"><h2>NR3C1</h2></div><div class="entry-overview-header">Organism</div><div id="content-organism" class="entry-overview-content"><em>Homo sapiens (Human)</em></div><div id="content-status-header" class="entry-overview-header entry-header">Status</div><div id="content-status" class="entry-overview-content"><a title="Reviewed (Swiss-Prot)" data-icon="s" class="icon-uniprot reviewed-icon tooltipped" href="/manual/entry_status"><span>Reviewed</span></a><span class="sep">-</span><span>Annotation score: </span><span class="context-help bin-score tooltipped-click"><svg width="66px" height="12px"><defs><circle id="o" r="5px" cy="6px" stroke="#00709B" fill="white" cx="8px"></circle><circle id="i" r="3.5px" cy="6px" fill="#00709B"></circle></defs><use xlink:href="#o" x="0px"></use><use xlink:href="#o" x="12px"></use><use xlink:href="#o" x="24px"></use><use xlink:href="#o" x="36px"></use><use xlink:href="#o" x="48px"></use><use xlink:href="#i" x="8px"></use><use xlink:href="#i" x="20px"></use><use xlink:href="#i" x="32px"></use><use xlink:href="#i" x="44px"></use><use xlink:href="#i" x="56px"></use></svg><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent"><p>Annotation score:5 out of 5</p>
                                    &lt;p>The annotation score provides a heuristic measure of the annotation content of a UniProtKB entry or proteome. This score &lt;strong>cannot&lt;/strong> be used as a measure of the accuracy of the annotation as we cannot define the 'correct annotation' for any given protein.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/annotation_score' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span></span><span class="context-help tooltipped-click"><span class="sep">-</span>Experimental evidence at protein level<sup>i</sup><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This indicates the type of evidence that supports the existence of the protein. Note that the 'protein existence' evidence does not give information on the accuracy or correctness of the sequence(s) displayed.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/protein_existence' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span></span></div></div><div style="display:none" id="closedSectionsMsg"><h4>Select a section on the left to see content.</h4></div><div class="section " id="function"><h2><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-0"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This section provides any useful information about the protein, mostly biological knowledge.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/function_section' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Function<sup>i</sup></span></h2><div class="annotation" property="hasPart" typeof="CreativeWork"><span property="text">Receptor for glucocorticoids (GC) (PubMed:<a href="/citations/27120390">27120390</a>). Has a dual mode of action: as a transcription factor that binds to glucocorticoid response elements (GRE), both for nuclear and mitochondrial DNA, and as a modulator of other transcription factors. Affects inflammatory responses, cellular proliferation and differentiation in target tissues. Involved in chromatin remodeling (PubMed:<a href="/citations/9590696">9590696</a>). Plays a role in rapid mRNA degradation by binding to the 5' UTR of target mRNAs and interacting with PNRC2 in a ligand-dependent manner which recruits the RNA helicase UPF1 and the mRNA-decapping enzyme DCP1A, leading to RNA decay (PubMed:<a href="/citations/25775514">25775514</a>). Could act as a coactivator for STAT5-dependent transcription upon growth hormone (GH) stimulation and could reveal an essential role of hepatic GR in the control of body growth (By similarity).<span class="attribution ECO250"><span class="attributionHeader ">By similarity<span class="showHideEvidence caret_grey displayThisInline"></span></span><span style="display:none" class="evidenceContainer"><p class="attributionExplain"><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-1"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">&#xd;
                                    &lt;p>Manually curated information which has been propagated from a related experimentally characterized protein.&lt;/p>&#xd;
&#xd;
&lt;p>&lt;a href="/manual/evidences#ECO:0000250">More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p>&#xd;
                                </span></span>Manual assertion inferred from sequence similarity to<sup>i</sup></span></p><ul><li><a href="P06537">UniProtKB:P06537 (GCR_MOUSE)</a></li></ul></span></span><span class="attribution ECO269"><span class="attributionHeader ">3 Publications<span class="showHideEvidence caret_grey displayThisInline"></span></span><span style="display:none" class="evidenceContainer"><p class="attributionExplain"><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-2"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">&#xd;
                                    &lt;p>Manually curated information for which there is published experimental evidence.&lt;/p>&#xd;

Has intrinsic transcriptional activity independent of isoform <a href="P04150#P04150" onclick="ensureIsoformSequenceVisible('P04150'); return true;">Alpha</a> when both isoforms are coexpressed (PubMed:<a href="/citations/19248771">19248771</a>, PubMed:<a href="/citations/26711253">26711253</a>). Loses this transcription modulator function on its own (PubMed:<a href="/citations/20484466">20484466</a>). Has no hormone-binding activity (PubMed:<a href="/citations/8621628">8621628</a>). May play a role in controlling glucose metabolism by maintaining insulin sensitivity (By similarity). Reduces hepatic gluconeogenesis through down-regulation of PEPCK in an isoform Alpha-dependent manner (PubMed:<a href="/citations/26711253">26711253</a>). Aggregation and nuclear localization of expanded polyglutamine proteins are regulated cellular processes that can be modulated by this receptor, a well-characterized transcriptional regulator.<span class="attribution ECO269"><span class="attributionHeader ">1 Publication<span class="showHideEvidence caret_grey displayThisInline"></span></span><span style="display:none" class="evidenceContainer"><p class="attributionExplain"><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-2">Manual assertion based on experiment in<sup>i</sup></span></p><ul><li><div class="P04150#ref27 referenceAttribution"><div class="reference_header">Ref.27</div><div class="reference_content"><div property="citation" resource="http://purl.uniprot.org/citations/10639135" typeof="ScholarlyArticle"><strong property="name">"Regulation of expanded polyglutamine protein aggregation and nuclear localization by the glucocorticoid receptor."</strong><br/><a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Diamond+M.I.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Diamond M.I.</a>, <a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Robinson+M.R.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Robinson M.R.</a>, <a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Yamamoto+K.R.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Yamamoto K.R.</a><br/><a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1073/pnas.97.2.657">Proc.                                     &lt;p>The &lt;a href="http://www.geneontology.org/">Gene Ontology (GO)&lt;/a> project provides a set of hierarchical controlled vocabulary split into 3 categories:&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/gene_ontology' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>GO - Molecular function<sup>i</sup></span></h4><ul class="noNumbering molecular_function"><li><a href="https://www.ebi.ac.uk/QuickGO/term/GO:0001047" onclick="window.ga('UniProt-Entry-View', 'click', 'Display-GO-Term');">core promoter binding</a><span class="attribution ECO314"><span class="attributionHeader"> Source: CAFA<span class="showHideEvidence caret_grey displayThisInline"></span></span><span class="gosource evidenceContainer" style="display:none"><span class="goa attributionExplain"><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-7"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">&#xd;

                                    &lt;p>Inferred from Mutant Phenotype&lt;/p>&#xd;
&#xd;
&lt;p>Describes annotations that are concluded from looking at variations or changes in a gene product such as mutations or abnormal levels and includes techniques such as knockouts, overexpression, anti-sense experiments and use of specific protein inhibitors.&lt;/p>&#xd;

class="section " id="names_and_taxonomy"><h2><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-15"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This section provides information about the protein and gene name(s) and synonym(s) and about the organism that is the source of the protein sequence.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/names_and_taxonomy_section' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Names &amp; Taxonomy<sup>i</sup></span></h2><table class="databaseTable"><tr><td><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-16"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This subsection of the &lt;a href="http://www.uniprot.org/help/names%5Fand%5Ftaxonomy%5Fsection">Names and taxonomy&lt;/a> section provides an exhaustive list of all names of the protein, from commonly used to obsolete, to allow unambiguous identification of a protein.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/protein_names' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Protein names<sup>i</sup></span></td><td><div><div><span title="The name recommended by the UniProt consortium." class="inner-title">Recommended name:</span></div><span property="name" class="recommended-name"><strong>Glucocorticoid receptor</strong></span><div><span title="Abbreviation of the full name or an acronym." class="listify2 inner-title">Short name: </span></div><div property="alternateName">GR</div><div><span title="A synonym of the recommended name." class="inner-title">Alternative name(s):</span></div><div><div property="alternateName" class="listify">Nuclear receptor subfamily 3 group C member 1</div></div></div></td></tr><tr><td id="gene_name_table"><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-17"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This subsection of the &lt;a href="http://www.uniprot.org/help/names%5Fand%5Ftaxonomy%5Fsection">Names and taxonomy&lt;/a> section indicates the name(s) of the gene(s) that code for the protein sequence(s) described in the entry. Four distinct tokens exist: 'Name', 'Synonyms', 'Ordered locus names' and 'ORF names'.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/gene_name' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Gene names<sup>i</sup></span></td><td class="noBorders"><div class="inner-title" property="mentions" typeof="CreativeWork">Name:<strong property="name"><a href="https://www.genenames.org/data/gene-symbol-report/#!/hgnc_id/HGNC:7978">NR3C1</a></strong><div><span>Synonyms:</span><span property="alternateName">GRL</span></div></div></td></tr><tr><td><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-18"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This subsection of the &lt;a href="http://www.uniprot.org/help/names%5Fand%5Ftaxonomy%5Fsection">Names and taxonomy&lt;/a> section provides information on the name(s) of the organism that is the source of the protein sequence.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/organism-name' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Organism<sup>i</sup></span></td><td><strong><a href="/taxonomy/9606">Homo sapiens (Human)</a></strong></td></tr><tr><td><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-19"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This subsection of the &lt;a href="http://www.uniprot.org/help/names%5Fand%5Ftaxonomy%5Fsection">Names and taxonomy&lt;/a> section shows the unique identifier assigned by the NCBI to the source organism of the protein. This is known as the 'taxonomic identifier' or 'taxid'.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/taxonomic_identifier' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Taxonomic identifier<sup>i</sup></span></td><td><a property="mentions" href="/taxonomy/9606">9606</a>  [<a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Taxonomy/Browser/wwwtax.cgi?lvl=0&amp;id=9606">NCBI</a>]</td></tr><tr><td><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-20"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This subsection of the &lt;a href="http://www.uniprot.org/help/names%5Fand%5Ftaxonomy%5Fsection">Names and taxonomy&lt;/a> section contains the taxonomic hierarchical classification lineage of the source organism. It lists the nodes as they appear top-down in the taxonomic tree, with the more general grouping listed first.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/taxonomic_lineage' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Taxonomic lineage<sup>i</sup></span></td><td><span style="display:none" class="hiddenTaxon"><a href="/taxonomy/131567">cellular organisms</a> ›                                     &lt;p>This subsection of the &lt;a href="http://www.uniprot.org/help/names%5Fand%5Ftaxonomy%5Fsection">Names and taxonomy&lt;/a> section is present for entries that are part of a &lt;a href="http://www.uniprot.org/proteomes">proteome&lt;/a>, i.e. of a set of proteins thought to be expressed by organisms whose genomes have been completely sequenced.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/proteomes_manual' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Proteomes<sup>i</sup></span></td><td><ul><li><a href="/proteomes/UP000005640">UP000005640</a><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-22"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>A UniProt &lt;a href="http://www.uniprot.org/manual/proteomes%5Fmanual">proteome&lt;/a> can consist of several components.&lt;br>&lt;/br>The component name refers to the genomic component encoding a set of proteins.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/proteome_component' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span> Component<sup>i</sup></span>: Chromosome 5 </li></ul></td></tr></table><h4 id="section_x-ref_organism" class="xref_category">Organism-specific databases</h4><table class="databaseTable ORGANISM"><tr><td><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-23"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent"><p>Human Gene Nomenclature Database</p><a href="/database/DB-0042">More...</a></span></span>HGNC<sup>i</sup></span></td><td><a href="https://www.genenames.org/data/gene-symbol-report/#!/hgnc_id/HGNC:7978">HGNC:7978</a> NR3C1<br/></td></tr><tr><td><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-24"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent"><p>Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man (OMIM)</p><a href="/database/DB-0062">More...</a></span></span>MIM<sup>i</sup></span></td><td><a href="https://www.omim.org/entry/138040">138040</a> gene<br/></td></tr><tr><td><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-25"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent"><p>neXtProt; the human protein knowledge platform</p><a href="/database/DB-0161">More...</a></span></span>neXtProt<sup>i</sup></span></td><td><a href="https://www.nextprot.org/entry/NX_P04150">NX_P04150</a><br/></td></tr></table></div><div class="section " id="subcellular_location"><h2><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-26"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">

Each mitochondrion is surrounded by a double limiting membrane. The inner membrane is highly invaginated, and its projections are called cristae. Mitochondria are the sites of the reactions of oxidative phosphorylation, which result in the formation of ATP. The size and coding capacity of the mitochondrial DNA varies considerably in different organisms, and encodes rRNAs, tRNAs and essential mitochondrial proteins." data-icon="i"></a> <span class="attribution ECO269"><span class="attributionHeader ">1 Publication<span class="showHideEvidence caret_grey displayThisInline"></span></span><span style="display:none" class="evidenceContainer"><p class="attributionExplain"><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-2">Manual assertion based on experiment in<sup>i</sup></span></p><ul><li><div class="P04150#ref55 referenceAttribution"><div class="reference_header">Ref.55</div><div class="reference_content"><div property="citation" resource="http://purl.uniprot.org/citations/21664385" typeof="ScholarlyArticle"><strong property="name">"Glucocorticoids induce mitochondrial gene transcription in HepG2 cells: role of the mitochondrial glucocorticoid receptor."</strong><br/><a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Psarra+A.M.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Psarra A.M.</a>, <a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Sekeris+C.E.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Sekeris C.E.</a><br/><a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.bbamcr.2011.05.014">Biochim. This three-dimensional, jelly-like lattice interconnects and supports the other solid structures. The cytosol (the soluble portion of the cytoplasm outside the organelles) is mostly composed of water and many low molecular weight compounds. In eukaryotes, the cytoplasm also contains a network of cytoplasmic filaments (cytoskeleton)." data-icon="i"></a> <span class="attribution ECO269"><span class="attributionHeader ">5 Publications<span class="showHideEvidence caret_grey displayThisInline"></span></span><span style="display:none" class="evidenceContainer"><p class="attributionExplain"><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-2">Manual assertion based on experiment in<sup>i</sup></span></p><ul><li><div class="P04150#ref19 referenceAttribution"><div class="reference_header">Ref.19</div><div class="reference_content"><div property="citation" resource="http://purl.uniprot.org/citations/8621628" typeof="ScholarlyArticle"><strong property="name">"The human glucocorticoid receptor beta isoform. Mutat. 37:794-803(2016)</a>  [<a property="sameAs" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27120390">PubMed</a>] [<a property="sameAs" href="https://europepmc.org/abstract/MED/27120390">Europe PMC</a>] [<a href="/citations/27120390">Abstract</a>]</div><div class="citedFor"><span class="details"><strong>Cited for:</strong></span> VARIANTS GCCR SER-477; CYS-478 AND PRO-672, CHARACTERIZATION OF VARIANTS GCCR SER-477; CYS-478 AND CYS-478, FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.</div></div></div></li></ul></span></span></h6><div>The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.</div><div class="disseaseDescription"><span>Disease description</span>An autosomal dominant disease characterized by increased plasma cortisol concentration and high urinary free cortisol, resistance to adrenal suppression by dexamethasone, and the absence of Cushing syndrome typical signs. Clinical features include hypoglycemia, hypertension, metabolic alkalosis, chronic fatigue and profound anxiety.</div><a href="https://www.omim.org/entry/615962">Related information in OMIM</a><table class="featureTable" style="" id="Natural_variant_GCCR_section"><tr><th class="featkey_h">Feature key</th><th class="pos_h">Position(s)</th><th class="description_h">Description<span class="featactions_h">Actions</span></th><th class="graphview_h">Graphical view</th><th class="length_h">Length</th></tr><tr class="feature_row" property="hasPart" typeof="CreativeWork" resource="http://purl.uniprot.org/annotation/VAR_075799"><td><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-29"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">

                                    &lt;p>This subsection of the &lt;a href="http://www.uniprot.org/help/ptm%5Fprocessing%5Fsection">PTM/processing&lt;/a> section describes post-translational modifications (PTMs). This subsection &lt;strong>complements&lt;/strong> the information provided at the sequence level or describes modifications for which &lt;strong>position-specific data is not yet available&lt;/strong>.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/post-translational_modification' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Post-translational modification<sup>i</sup></span></h4><div class="annotation" property="hasPart" typeof="CreativeWork"><span property="text">Acetylation by CLOCK reduces its binding to glucocorticoid response elements and its transcriptional activity.<span class="attribution ECO269"><span class="attributionHeader ">2 Publications<span class="showHideEvidence caret_grey displayThisInline"></span></span><span style="display:none" class="evidenceContainer"><p class="attributionExplain"><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-2">Manual assertion based on experiment in<sup>i</sup></span></p><ul><li><div class="P04150#ref49 referenceAttribution"><div class="reference_header">Ref.49</div><div class="reference_content"><div property="citation" resource="http://purl.uniprot.org/citations/19141540" CLOCK.</div></div></div></li></ul></span></span></span></div><div class="annotation" property="hasPart" typeof="CreativeWork"><span property="text">Increased proteasome-mediated degradation in response to glucocorticoids (PubMed:<a href="/citations/11555652">11555652</a>). Isoform <a href="P04150#P04150-8" onclick="ensureIsoformSequenceVisible('P04150-8'); return true;">Alpha-B</a> appears to be more susceptible to proteolytic degradation than isoform <a href="P04150#P04150" onclick="ensureIsoformSequenceVisible('P04150'); return true;">Alpha</a> (PubMed:<a href="/citations/11435610">11435610</a>).<span class="attribution ECO269"><span class="attributionHeader ">2 Publications<span class="showHideEvidence caret_grey displayThisInline"></span></span><span style="display:none" class="evidenceContainer"><p class="attributionExplain"><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-2">Manual assertion based on experiment in<sup>i</sup></span></p><ul><li><div class="P04150#ref29 referenceAttribution"><div class="reference_header">Ref.29</div><div class="reference_content"><div property="citation" resource="http://purl.uniprot.org/citations/11555652" typeof="ScholarlyArticle"><strong property="name">"Proteasome-mediated glucocorticoid receptor degradation restricts transcriptional signaling by glucocorticoids."</strong><br/><a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Wallace+A.D.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Wallace A.D.</a>, <a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Cidlowski+J.A.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Cidlowski J.A.</a><br/><a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1074/jbc.m106033200">J. Biol. Chem. 276:42714-42721(2001)</a>  [<a property="sameAs" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11555652">PubMed</a>] [<a property="sameAs" href="https://europepmc.org/abstract/MED/11555652">Europe PMC</a>] [<a href="/citations/11555652">Abstract</a>]</div><div class="citedFor"><span class="details"><strong>Cited for:</strong></span> GLUCOCORTICOID-MEDIATED DOWN-REGULATION.</div></div></div></li><li><div class="P04150#ref31 referenceAttribution"><div class="reference_header">Ref.31</div><div class="reference_content"><div property="citation" resource="http://purl.uniprot.org/citations/11435610" typeof="ScholarlyArticle"><strong property="name">"Molecular identification and characterization of A and B forms of the glucocorticoid receptor."</strong><br/><a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Yudt+M.R.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Yudt M.R.</a>, <a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Cidlowski+J.A.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Cidlowski J.A.</a><br/><a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1210/mend.15.7.0667">Mol. Endocrinol. 15:1093-1103(2001)</a>  [<a property="sameAs" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11435610">PubMed</a>] [<a property="sameAs" href="https://europepmc.org/abstract/MED/11435610">Europe PMC</a>] [<a href="/citations/11435610">Abstract</a>]</div><div class="citedFor"><span class="details"><strong>Cited for:</strong></span> FUNCTION (ISOFORMS ALPHA AND ALPHA-B), ALTERNATIVE INITIATION, MUTAGENESIS OF MET-1 AND MET-27.</div></div></div></li></ul></span></span></span></div><div class="annotation" property="hasPart" typeof="CreativeWork"><span property="text">Phosphorylated in the absence of hormone; becomes hyperphosphorylated in the presence of glucocorticoid. The Ser-203, Ser-226 and Ser-404-phosphorylated forms are mainly cytoplasmic, and the Ser-211-phosphorylated form is nuclear (PubMed:<a href="/citations/12000743">12000743</a>, PubMed:<a href="/citations/18838540">18838540</a>). Phosphorylation at Ser-211 increases transcriptional activity (PubMed:<a href="/citations/12000743">12000743</a>, PubMed:<a href="/citations/18483179">18483179</a>). Phosphorylation at Ser-203, Ser-226 and Ser-404 decreases signaling capacity (PubMed:<a href="/citations/12000743">12000743</a>, PubMed:<a href="/citations/18483179">18483179</a>, PubMed:<a href="/citations/18838540">18838540</a>). Phosphorylation at Ser-404 may protect from glucocorticoid-induced apoptosis (PubMed:<a href="/citations/18838540">18838540</a>). Phosphorylation at Ser-203 and Ser-211 is not required in regulation of chromosome segregation (PubMed:<a href="/citations/25847991">25847991</a>). May be dephosphorylated by PPP5C, attenuates NR3C1 action (By similarity).<span class="attribution ECO250"><span class="attributionHeader ">By similarity<span class="showHideEvidence caret_grey displayThisInline"></span></span><span style="display:none" class="evidenceContainer"><p class="attributionExplain"><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-1">Manual assertion inferred from sequence similarity to<sup>i</sup></span></p><ul><li><a href="P06537">UniProtKB:P06537 (GCR_MOUSE)</a></li></ul></span></span><span class="attribution ECO269"><span class="attributionHeader ">4 Publications<span class="showHideEvidence caret_grey displayThisInline"></span></span><span style="display:none" class="evidenceContainer"><p class="attributionExplain"><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-2">Manual assertion based on experiment in<sup>i</sup></span></p><ul><li><div class="P04150#ref34 referenceAttribution"><div class="reference_header">Ref.34</div><div class="reference_content"><div property="citation" resource="http://purl.uniprot.org/citations/12000743" typeof="ScholarlyArticle"><strong property="name">"Deciphering the phosphorylation 'code' of the glucocorticoid receptor in vivo."</strong><br/><a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Wang+Z.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Wang Z.</a>, <a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Frederick+J.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Frederick J.</a>, <a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Garabedian+M.J.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Garabedian M.J.</a><br/><a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1074/jbc.m110530200">J. Sumoylation at Lys-703 positively regulates its transcriptional activity in the presence of RWDD3 (By similarity). Sumoylation at Lys-277 and Lys-293 is dispensable whereas sumoylation at Lys-703 is critical for the stimulatory effect of RWDD3 on its transcriptional activity (By similarity). Heat shock increases sumoylation in a RWDD3-dependent manner (By similarity).<span class="attribution ECO250"><span class="attributionHeader ">By similarity<span class="showHideEvidence caret_grey displayThisInline"></span></span><span style="display:none" class="evidenceContainer"><p class="attributionExplain"><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-1">Manual assertion inferred from sequence similarity to<sup>i</sup></span></p><ul><li><a href="P06536">UniProtKB:P06536 (GCR_RAT)</a></li></ul></span></span><span class="attribution ECO269"><span class="attributionHeader ">1 Publication<span class="showHideEvidence caret_grey displayThisInline"></span></span><span style="display:none" class="evidenceContainer"><p class="attributionExplain"><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-2">Manual assertion based on experiment in<sup>i</sup></span></p><ul><li><div class="P04150#ref33 referenceAttribution"><div class="reference_header">Ref.33</div><div class="reference_content"><div property="citation" resource="http://purl.uniprot.org/citations/12144530" typeof="ScholarlyArticle"><strong property="name">"Small ubiquitin-related modifier-1 (SUMO-1) modification of the glucocorticoid receptor."</strong><br/><a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Tian+S.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Tian S.</a>, <a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Poukka+H.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Poukka H.</a>, <a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Palvimo+J.J.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Palvimo J.J.</a>, <a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Jaenne+O.A.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Jaenne O.A.</a><br/><a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1042/bj20021085">Biochem. href="https://www.phosphosite.org/uniprotAccAction?id=P04150">P04150</a><br/></td></tr></table></div><div class="section " id="expression"><h2><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-58"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This section provides information on the expression of a gene at the mRNA or protein level in cells or in tissues of multicellular organisms.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/expression_section' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Expression<sup>i</sup></span></h2><h4><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-59"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This subsection of the 'Expression' section provides information on the expression of a gene at the mRNA or protein level in cells or in tissues of multicellular organisms. By default, the information is derived from experiments at the mRNA level, unless specified 'at protein level'.&lt;br>&lt;/br>Examples: &lt;a href="http://www.uniprot.org/uniprot/P92958#expression">P92958&lt;/a>, &lt;a href="http://www.uniprot.org/uniprot/Q8TDN4#expression">Q8TDN4&lt;/a>, &lt;a href="http://www.uniprot.org/uniprot/O14734#expression">O14734&lt;/a>&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/tissue_specificity' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Tissue specificity<sup>i</sup></span></h4><div class="annotation" property="hasPart" typeof="CreativeWork"><span property="text">Widely expressed including bone, stomach, lung, liver, colon, breast, ovary, pancreas and kidney (PubMed:<a href="/citations/25847991">25847991</a>). In the heart, detected in left and right atria, left and right ventricles, aorta, apex, intraventricular septum, and atrioventricular node as well as whole adult and fetal heart (PubMed:<a href="/citations/10902803">10902803</a>). Isoform Beta: Widely expressed including brain, bone marrow, thymus, spleen, liver, kidney, pancreas, lung, fat, skeletal muscle, heart, placenta and blood leukocytes (PubMed:<a href="/citations/7769088">7769088</a>, PubMed:<a href="/citations/8621628">8621628</a>). Isoform Alpha-2: Expressed at low level.<span class="attribution ECO269"><span class="attributionHeader ">4 Publications<span class="showHideEvidence caret_grey displayThisInline"></span></span><span style="display:none" class="evidenceContainer"><p class="attributionExplain"><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-2">Manual assertion based on experiment in<sup>i</sup></span></p><ul><li><div class="P04150#ref18 referenceAttribution"><div class="reference_header">Ref.18</div><div class="reference_content"><div property="citation" resource="http://purl.uniprot.org/citations/7769088" typeof="ScholarlyArticle"><strong property="name">"Glucocorticoid receptor beta, a potential endogenous inhibitor of glucocorticoid action in humans."</strong><br/><a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Bamberger+C.M.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Bamberger C.M.</a>, <a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Bamberger+A.M.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Bamberger A.M.</a>, <a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22de+Castro+M.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">de Castro M.</a>, <a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Chrousos+G.P.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Chrousos G.P.</a><br/><a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1172/jci117943">J.                                     &lt;p>This subsection of the 'Expression' section reports the experimentally proven effects of inducers and repressors (usually chemical compounds or environmental factors) on the level of protein (or mRNA) expression (up-regulation, down-regulation, constitutive expression).&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/induction' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Induction<sup>i</sup></span></h4><div class="annotation" property="hasPart" typeof="CreativeWork"><span property="text">Isoform Alpha: Up-regulated by TNF (at protein level). Isoform Beta: Up-regulated by TNF and becomes the predominant isoform which may lead to glucocorticoid resistance (at protein level).<span class="attribution ECO269"><span class="attributionHeader ">1 Publication<span class="showHideEvidence caret_grey displayThisInline"></span></span><span style="display:none" class="evidenceContainer"><p class="attributionExplain"><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-2">Manual assertion based on experiment in<sup>i</sup></span></p><ul><li><div class="P04150#ref32 referenceAttribution"><div class="reference_header">Ref.32</div><div class="reference_content"><div property="citation" resource="http://purl.uniprot.org/citations/11381138" typeof="ScholarlyArticle"><strong property="name">"Proinflammatory cytokines regulate human glucocorticoid receptor gene expression and lead to the accumulation of the dominant negative beta isoform: a mechanism for the generation of glucocorticoid resistance."</strong><br/><a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Webster+J.C.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Webster J.C.</a>, <a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Oakley+R.H.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Oakley R.H.</a>, <a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Jewell+C.M.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Jewell C.M.</a>, <a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Cidlowski+J.A.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Cidlowski J.A.</a><br/><a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1073/pnas.121455098">Proc. PMC</a>] [<a href="/citations/11381138">Abstract</a>]</div><div class="citedFor"><span class="details"><strong>Cited for:</strong></span> INDUCTION (ISOFORMS ALPHA AND BETA).</div></div></div></li></ul></span></span></span></div><h4 id="section_x-ref_expression" class="xref_category">Gene expression databases</h4><table class="databaseTable EXPRESSION"><tr><td><span and differential<br/></td></tr><tr><td><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-63"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent"><p>Genevisible search portal to normalized and curated expression data from Genevestigator</p><a href="/database/DB-0194">More...</a></span></span>Genevisible<sup>i</sup></span></td><td><a href="https://genevisible.com/tissues/HS/UniProt/P04150">P04150</a> HS<br/></td></tr></table><h4 id="section_x-ref_organism" class="xref_category">Organism-specific databases</h4><table class="databaseTable ORGANISM"><tr><td><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-64"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent"><p>Human Protein Atlas</p><a href="/database/DB-0046">More...</a></span></span>HPA<sup>i</sup></span></td><td><a href="http://www.proteinatlas.org/tissue_profile.php?antibody_id=CAB010435">CAB010435</a><br/><a href="http://www.proteinatlas.org/tissue_profile.php?antibody_id=HPA004248">HPA004248</a><br/></td></tr></table></div><div class="section " id="interaction"><h2><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-65"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This section provides information on the quaternary structure of a protein and on interaction(s) with other proteins or protein complexes.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/interaction_section' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Interaction<sup>i</sup></span></h2><h4><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-66"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This subsection of the &lt;a href="http://www.uniprot.org/help/interaction%5Fsection">'Interaction'&lt;/a> section provides information about the protein quaternary structure and interaction(s) with other proteins or protein complexes (with the exception of physiological receptor-ligand interactions which are annotated in the &lt;a href="http://www.uniprot.org/help/function%5Fsection">'Function'&lt;/a> section).&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/subunit_structure' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Subunit structure<sup>i</sup></span></h4><div class="annotation" property="hasPart" typeof="CreativeWork"><div><p style="margin-bottom:5px" property="text">Heteromultimeric cytoplasmic complex with HSP90AA1, HSPA1A/HSPA1B, and FKBP5 or another immunophilin such as PPID, STIP1, or the immunophilin homolog PPP5C (PubMed:<a href="/citations/21730050">21730050</a>). Upon ligand binding FKBP5 dissociates from the complex and FKBP4 takes its place, thereby linking the complex to dynein and mediating transport to the nucleus, where the complex dissociates (By similarity). Probably forms a complex composed of chaperones HSP90 and HSP70, co-chaperones CDC37, PPP5C, TSC1 and client protein TSC2, CDK4, AKT, RAF1 and NR3C1; this complex does not contain co-chaperones STIP1/HOP and PTGES3/p23 (PubMed:<a href="/citations/29127155">29127155</a>). Directly interacts with UNC45A (PubMed:<a href="/citations/16478993">16478993</a>). Binds to DNA as a homodimer, and as heterodimer with NR3C2 or the retinoid X receptor. Binds STAT5A and STAT5B homodimers and heterodimers (By similarity). </p><p style="margin-bottom:5px" property="text">Interacts with NRIP1, POU2F1, POU2F2 and TRIM28 (By similarity). </p><p style="margin-bottom:5px" property="text">Interacts with several coactivator complexes, including the SMARCA4 complex, CREBBP/EP300, TADA2L (Ada complex) and p160 coactivators such as NCOA2 and NCOA6 (PubMed:<a href="/citations/10866662">10866662</a>, PubMed:<a href="/citations/12151000">12151000</a>, PubMed:<a href="/citations/12686538">12686538</a>, PubMed:<a href="/citations/9154805">9154805</a>, PubMed:<a href="/citations/9590696">9590696</a>). Interaction with BAG1 inhibits transactivation (PubMed:<a href="/citations/10477749">10477749</a>). </p><p style="margin-bottom:5px" property="text">Interacts with HEXIM1, PELP1 and TGFB1I1 (PubMed:<a href="/citations/12415108">12415108</a>, PubMed:<a href="/citations/15211577">15211577</a>, PubMed:<a href="/citations/15941832">15941832</a>). </p><p style="margin-bottom:5px" property="text">Interacts with NCOA1 (PubMed:<a href="/citations/9590696">9590696</a>). </p><p style="margin-bottom:5px" property="text">Interacts with NCOA3, SMARCA4, SMARCC1, SMARCD1, and SMARCE1 (By similarity). </p><p style="margin-bottom:5px" property="text">Interacts with CLOCK, CRY1 and CRY2 in a ligand-dependent fashion (PubMed:<a href="/citations/19141540">19141540</a>, PubMed:<a href="/citations/21980503">21980503</a>, PubMed:<a href="/citations/22170608">22170608</a>). </p><p style="margin-bottom:5px" property="text">Interacts with CIART (By similarity). </p><p style="margin-bottom:5px" property="text">Interacts with RWDD3 (By similarity). </p><p style="margin-bottom:5px" property="text">Interacts with UBE2I/UBC9 and this interaction is enhanced in the presence of RWDD3 (By similarity). </p><p style="margin-bottom:5px" property="text">Interacts with GRIP1 (PubMed:<a href="/citations/15769988">15769988</a>, PubMed:<a href="/citations/17635946">17635946</a>). </p><p style="margin-bottom:5px" property="text">Interacts with NR4A3 (via nuclear receptor DNA-binding domain), represses transcription activity of NR4A3 on the POMC promoter Nur response element (NurRE) (PubMed:<a href="/citations/15591535">15591535</a>). Directly interacts with PNRC2 to attract and form a complex with UPF1 and DCP1A; the interaction leads to rapid mRNA degradation (PubMed:<a href="/citations/25775514">25775514</a>). </p><p style="margin-bottom:5px" property="text">Interacts with GSK3B (PubMed:<a href="/citations/18838540">18838540</a>). </p><p style="margin-bottom:5px" property="text">Interacts with FNIP1 and FNIP2 (PubMed:<a href="/citations/27353360">27353360</a>). </p><p style="margin-bottom:5px" property="text">Interacts (via C-terminus) with HNRNPU (via C-terminus) (PubMed:<a href="/citations/9353307">9353307</a>). </p><p style="margin-bottom:5px" property="text">Interacts with MCM3AP (PubMed:<a href="/citations/16914116">16914116</a>). </p><p style="margin-bottom:5px" property="text">Interacts (via domain NR LBD) with HSP90AA1 and HSP90AB1 (By similarity). In the absence of hormonal ligand, interacts with TACC1 (PubMed:<a href="/citations/20078863">20078863</a>).</p><span class="attribution ECO250"><span class="attributionHeader ">By similarity<span class="showHideEvidence caret_grey displayThisInline"></span></span><span style="display:none" class="evidenceContainer"><p class="attributionExplain"><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-1">Manual assertion inferred from sequence similarity to<sup>i</sup></span></p><ul><li><a href="P06536">UniProtKB:P06536 (GCR_RAT)</a></li><li><a href="P06537">UniProtKB:P06537 (GCR_MOUSE)</a></li></ul></span></span><span class="attribution ECO269"><span class="attributionHeader ">24 Publications<span class="showHideEvidence caret_grey displayThisInline"></span></span><span style="display:none" class="evidenceContainer"><p class="attributionExplain"><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-2">Manual assertion based on experiment in<sup>i</sup></span></p><ul><li><div class="P04150#ref20 referenceAttribution"><div class="reference_header">Ref.20</div><div class="reference_content"><div property="citation" class="featactions_h">Actions</span></th><th class="graphview_h">Graphical view</th><th class="length_h">Length</th></tr><tr class="feature_row" property="hasPart" typeof="CreativeWork"><td><span                                     &lt;p>This subsection of the 'Family and Domains' section describes the position of regions of compositional bias within the protein and the particular amino acids that are over-represented within those regions.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/compbias' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Compositional bias<sup>i</sup></span></td><td class="numeric"><a class="position tooltipped" title="BLAST subsequence" href="/blast/?about=P04150[399-418]&amp;key=Compositional bias">399 – 418</a></td><td class="featdescription"><span property="text">Glu/Pro/Ser/Thr-rich (PEST region)</span><span class="featactions"><a class="icon icon-static tooltipped subsequences" data-icon="b" id="P04150_399-418_" title="Add to basket">Add</a> <a class="icon icon-functional tooltipped blastSubsequences" data-icon="t" title="View this subsequence or run a BLAST search on it.">BLAST</a></span></td><td class="ft-sequence"><svg class="featureImage"><rect x="51.222%" width="2.574%" height="100%" class="featureRect"></rect></svg></td><td class="featlength numeric">20</td></tr></table><h4><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-89"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This subsection of the 'Family and domains' section provides general information on the biological role of a domain. The term 'domain' is intended here in its wide acceptation, it may be a structural domain, a transmembrane region or a functional domain. Several domains are described in this subsection.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/domain_cc' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Domain<sup>i</sup></span></h4><div class="annotation" property="hasPart" typeof="CreativeWork">Composed of three domains: a modulating N-terminal domain, a DNA-binding domain and a C-terminal ligand-binding domain (PubMed:<a href="/citations/3841189">3841189</a>). The ligand-binding domain is required for correct chromosome segregation during mitosis although ligand binding is not required (PubMed:<a href="/citations/25847991">25847991</a>).<span hit<br/></td></tr></table></div><div class="section " id="sequences"><h2><span class="context-help tooltipped-click"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This section displays by default the canonical protein sequence and upon request all isoforms described in the entry. It also includes information pertinent to the sequence(s), including &lt;a href="http://www.uniprot.org/help/sequence%5Flength">length&lt;/a> and &lt;a href="http://www.uniprot.org/help/sequences">molecular weight&lt;/a>. The information is filed in different subsections. The current subsections and their content are listed below:&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/sequences_section' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Sequence<span>s (16+)<sup>i</sup></span></span></h2><p class="details"><span><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-108"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This subsection of the &lt;a href="http://www.uniprot.org/help/sequences%5Fsection">Sequence&lt;/a> section indicates if the &lt;a href="http://www.uniprot.org/help/canonical%5Fand%5Fisoforms">canonical sequence&lt;/a> displayed by default in the entry is complete or not.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/sequence_status' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Sequence status<sup>i</sup></span></span><span class="tooltipped" title="The displayed sequence is complete.">: Complete.</span></p>This entry describes <strong>16</strong><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-109"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This subsection of the 'Sequence' section lists the alternative protein sequences (isoforms) that can be generated from the same gene by a single or by the combination of up to four biological events (alternative promoter usage, alternative splicing, alternative initiation and ribosomal frameshifting). Additionally, this section gives relevant information on each alternative protein isoform.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/alternative_products' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span> isoforms<sup>i</sup></span> produced by <span class="alternative_products"><strong>alternative splicing</strong></span> and <span class="alternative_products"><strong>alternative initiation</strong></span>. <a href="#" id="alignIsoformsFromSection" title="Align this entry with its isoforms" class="icon icon-functional button tooltipped" data-icon="i">Align</a><script <span>Predominant physiological form.</span><span class="attribution ECO269"><span class="attributionHeader ">1 Publication<span class="showHideEvidence caret_grey displayThisInline"></span></span><span style="display:none" class="evidenceContainer"><p class="attributionExplain"><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-2">Manual assertion based on experiment in<sup>i</sup></span></p><ul><li><div class="P04150#ref38 referenceAttribution"><div class="reference_header">Ref.38</div><div class="reference_content"><div property="citation" resource="http://purl.uniprot.org/citations/15866175" typeof="ScholarlyArticle"><strong property="name">"Translational regulatory mechanisms generate N-terminal glucocorticoid receptor isoforms with unique transcriptional target genes."</strong><br/><a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Lu+N.Z.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Lu N.Z.</a>, <a href="/uniprot/?query=author:%22Cidlowski+J.A.%22&amp;sort=score" rel="nofollow">Cidlowski J.A.</a><br/><a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molcel.2005.03.025">Mol. Cell 18:331-342(2005)</a>  [<a property="sameAs" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15866175">PubMed</a>] [<a property="sameAs" href="https://europepmc.org/abstract/MED/15866175">Europe PMC</a>] [<a href="/citations/15866175">Abstract</a>]</div><div class="citedFor"><span class="details"><strong>Cited for:</strong></span> FUNCTION (ISOFORMS ALPHA; ALPHA-B; ALPHA-C1; ALPHA-C2; ALPHA-C3; ALPHA-D1; ALPHA-D2 AND ALPHA-D3), SUBCELLULAR LOCATION (ISOFORM ALPHA-B), ALTERNATIVE INITIATION (ISOFORMS ALPHA; ALPHA-B; ALPHA-C1; ALPHA-C2; ALPHA-C3; ALPHA-D1; ALPHA-D2 AND ALPHA-D3), MUTAGENESIS OF MET-1; MET-27; MET-86; MET-90; MET-98; MET-316; MET-331 AND MET-336.</div></div></div></li></ul></span></span></div><a class="show-link" id="P04150-show-link" href="#" style="display:none">Show »</a></div><div class="sequence-isoform-rightcol"><div><span class="sequence-field-header tooltiped" title="Sequence length.">Length:</span><span>777</span></div><div><span title="The mass of the unprocessed protein, in Daltons." class="sequence-field-header tooltiped">Mass (Da):</span><span>85,659</span></div><div><span class="sequence-field-header">Last modified:</span><span>November 1, 1986 - v1</span></div><div><span class="sequence-field-header"><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-111"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">&#xd;
                                    &lt;p>The checksum is a form of redundancy check that is calculated&#xd;
     from the sequence. It is useful for tracking sequence updates.&lt;/p>&#xd;
&#xd;
    &lt;p>It should be noted that while, in theory, two different sequences could&#xd;
     have the same checksum value, the likelihood that this would happen&#xd;
     is extremely low.&lt;/p>&#xd;
&#xd;
    &lt;p>However UniProtKB may contain entries with identical sequences in case&#xd;
     of multiple genes (paralogs).&lt;/p>&#xd;
&#xd;
    &lt;p>The checksum is computed as the sequence 64-bit Cyclic Redundancy Check value (CRC64)&#xd;
     using the generator polynomial: x&lt;sup>64&lt;/sup> + x&lt;sup>4&lt;/sup> + x&lt;sup>3&lt;/sup> + x + 1.&#xd;
     The algorithm is described in the ISO 3309 standard.&#xd;
    &lt;/p>&#xd;
&#xd;
    &lt;p class="publication">Press W.H., Flannery B.P., Teukolsky S.A. and Vetterling W.T.&lt;br />&#xd;
     &lt;strong>Cyclic redundancy and other checksums&lt;/strong>&lt;br />&#xd;
     &lt;a href="http://www.nrbook.com/b/bookcpdf.php">Numerical recipes in C 2nd ed., pp896-902, Cambridge University Press (1993)&lt;/a>)&lt;/p>&#xd;

                                    &lt;p>This subsection of the 'Sequence' section reports difference(s) between the canonical sequence (displayed by default in the entry) and the different sequence submissions merged in the entry. These various submissions may originate from different sequencing projects, different types of experiments, or different biological samples. Sequence conflicts are usually of unknown origin.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/conflict' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Sequence conflict<sup>i</sup></span></td><td class="numeric"><a class="position tooltipped" title="BLAST subsequence" href="/blast/?about=P04150[399]&amp;key=Sequence conflict">399</a></td><td class="featdescription">R → G in <a href="https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ena/data/view/BAD97314">BAD97314</a> (<a href="./P04150/publications/#ref7">Ref. 7</a>) <span class="attribution ECO305"><span class="attributionHeader tooltipped" title="Manual assertion inferred by curator">Curated</span></span></td><td class="ft-sequence"><svg class="featureImage"><rect x="51.222%" width="1%" height="100%" class="featureRect"></rect></svg></td><td class="featlength numeric">1</td></tr><tr class="feature_row" property="hasPart" typeof="CreativeWork"><td><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-113">Sequence conflict<sup>i</sup></span></td><td class="numeric"><a class="position tooltipped" title="BLAST subsequence" href="/blast/?about=P04150[754]&amp;key=Sequence conflict">754</a></td><td class="featdescription">A → T in <a href="https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ena/data/view/BAD97314">BAD97314</a> (<a href="./P04150/publications/#ref7">Ref. 7</a>) <span class="attribution ECO305"><span class="attributionHeader tooltipped" title="Manual assertion inferred by curator">Curated</span></span></td><td class="ft-sequence"><svg class="featureImage"><rect x="96.911%" width="1%" height="100%" class="featureRect"></rect></svg></td><td class="featlength numeric">1</td></tr></table><h4><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-114"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This subsection of the 'Sequence' section provides information on polymorphic variants. If the variant is associated with a disease state, the description of the latter can be found in the &lt;a href="http://www.uniprot.org/manual/involvement%5Fin%5Fdisease">'Involvement in disease'&lt;/a> subsection.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/polymorphism' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Polymorphism<sup>i</sup></span></h4><div class="annotation" property="hasPart" typeof="CreativeWork"><span property="text">Carriers of the 22-Glu-Lys-23 allele are relatively more resistant to the effects of GCs with respect to the sensitivity of the adrenal feedback mechanism than non-carriers, resulting in a better metabolic health profile. Carriers have a better survival than non-carriers, as well as lower serum CRP levels. The 22-Glu-Lys-23 polymorphism is associated with a sex-specific, beneficial body composition at young-adult age, as well as greater muscle strength in males.</span></div><h4>Natural variant</h4><table class="featureTable" style="" id="Natural_variant_section"><tr><th class="featkey_h">Feature key</th><th class="pos_h">Position(s)</th><th class="description_h">Description<span tipId-144"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This section provides general information on the entry.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/entry_information_section' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Entry information<sup>i</sup></span></h2><table><tr><td><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-145"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This subsection of the 'Entry information' section provides a mnemonic identifier for a UniProtKB entry, but it is not a stable identifier. Each reviewed entry is assigned a unique entry name upon integration into UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/entry_name' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Entry name<sup>i</sup></span></td><td colspan="2">GCR_HUMAN</td></tr><tr><td><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-146"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This subsection of the 'Entry information' section provides one or more accession number(s). These are stable identifiers and should be used to cite UniProtKB entries. Upon integration into UniProtKB, each entry is assigned a unique accession number, which is called 'Primary (citable) accession number'.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/accession_numbers' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Accession<sup>i</sup></span></td><td colspan="2"><span class="hidden" property="about"><a href="http://purl.uniprot.org/uniprot/P04150">P04150</a></span>Primary (citable) accession number: <strong property="identifier">P04150</strong><br/>Secondary accession number(s): A0ZXF9<span class="clickable"> <div id="ac_img1" class="icon_expand secondaryAcs" title="Show all accession numbers"></div> </span><span style="display:none">, B0LPG8, D3DQF4, F5ATB7, P04151, Q53EP5, </span>Q6N0A4</td></tr><tr id="history"><td rowspan="4"><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-147"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This subsection of the 'Entry information' section shows the date of integration of the entry into UniProtKB, the date of the last sequence update and the date of the last annotation modification ('Last modified'). The version number for both the entry and the &lt;a href="http://www.uniprot.org/help/canonical%5Fand%5Fisoforms">canonical sequence&lt;/a> are also displayed.&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/entry_history' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Entry history<sup>i</sup></span></td><td style="width: 18em;">Integrated into UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot: </td><td><span property="dateCreated">November 1, 1986</span></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 18em;">Last sequence update: </td><td>November 1, 1986</td></tr><tr><td style="width: 18em;">Last modified: </td><td><span property="dateModified">February 26, 2020</span></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2">This is version <span property="version">264</span> of the entry and version 1 of the sequence. <a href="/uniprot/P04150?version=*">See complete history.</a></td></tr><tr><td><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-148"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
                                    &lt;p>This subsection of the 'Entry information' section indicates whether the entry has been manually annotated and reviewed by UniProtKB curators or not, in other words, if the entry belongs to the Swiss-Prot section of UniProtKB (&lt;strong>reviewed&lt;/strong>) or to the computer-annotated TrEMBL section (&lt;strong>unreviewed&lt;/strong>).&lt;p>&lt;a href='/help/entry_status' target='_top'>More...&lt;/a>&lt;/p></span></span>Entry status<sup>i</sup></span></td><td colspan="2">Reviewed (UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot)</td></tr><tr><td><span class="acronym" title="Annotation program in charge of the current entry.">Annotation program</span></td><td colspan="2"><a href="/program/Chordata/" onclick="window.ga('UniProt-Entry-View', 'project', 'Chordata');">Chordata Protein Annotation Program</a></td></tr><tr class="achtung"><td>Disclaimer</td><td colspan="2">Any medical or genetic information present in this entry is provided for research, educational and informational purposes only. It is not in any way intended to be used as a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, treatment or care.</td></tr></table></div><div class="section " id="miscellaneous"><h2><span class="context-help tooltipped-click html tipId-149"><span style="display:none"><span class="toolTipContent">
